He was of course much nearer to the facts here than in the case of Cuthbert; indeed of many things he must have been an eye—witness. And the Lives of the Abbots are not unworthy to take their place beside the Ecclesi- astical History. But it would have been matter for regret had Bede's works supplanted wholly the works of his predecessors. The fewness of the MSS. in which these works exist shows that this contingency was very near occu1·ring‘². And this brings home to us the possibility, suggested many years ago by Lappenberg, that Bede’s Ecclesiastical History may. by its very excellence, have caused the loss of a large amount of earlier historical materials ³ 3 a question which arises also in the case of our Synoptic Gospels.
